conclusion: To determine the number of moments when the speed is 5 m/s based on the given displacement-time graph.
The graph shows displacement x (in meters) as a function of time t (in seconds). At t = 0, the displacement is 10 m. At t = 4 s, the displacement is -10 m.
Velocity is the rate of change of displacement with respect to time, given by the slope of the displacement-time graph. Speed is the magnitude of velocity.

The velocity at any point on the graph is the derivative of the displacement with respect to time, v = dx/dt. The slope of the tangent to the curve at any point gives the instantaneous velocity at that point.
We need to find points where the speed (magnitude of velocity) is 5 m/s, meaning points where the absolute value of the slope of the tangent to the curve is 5.
The curve is smooth and continuous, indicating a continuous change in velocity. The curve starts at 10 m and ends at -10 m, crossing the time axis at t = 2 s.

At t = 0, the slope is negative and steep, indicating a high negative velocity. As time progresses, the slope decreases in magnitude, reaching zero at the point where the curve is horizontal (around t = 2 s). After t = 2 s, the slope becomes positive and increases in magnitude.
We need to find two points where the slope magnitude is 5. One point will be before t = 2 s with a negative slope of -5 m/s. Another point will be after t = 2 s with a positive slope of 5 m/s.
There are two distinct moments within the 0 to 4 seconds interval where the speed is 5 m/s.
